She is particularly focused on using machine learning techniques to fit Parton Distribution Functions (PDFs) with data from colliders. Working with the NNPDF collaboration, Eva aims to enhance traditional approaches with novel machine learning models, specifically Bayesian Neural Networks, to improve the optimization of these fits and to gain deeper insights into the structure of the neural network itself. Her recent engagement with Keras, TensorFlow, and PyTorch is essential for her current projects, and she is keen to explore new methodologies that can bolster her research efforts.

Eva is deeply interested in the explainability of neural networks, particularly in the context of fitting Parton Distribution Functions. She recognizes that understanding the decision-making processes of complex models is crucial for ensuring their reliability and interpretability in scientific research. In her work with the AIPHY project, Eva strives to develop techniques that not only enhance model performance but also provide clear insights into how these models arrive at their predictions. This endeavor is aimed at bridging the gap between sophisticated algorithmic approaches and the intuitive understanding required in theoretical particle physics.

Eva is committed to optimizing the fitting pipelines used in the analysis of collider data for theoretical particle physics. Her work with the NNPDF collaboration emphasizes the importance of designing efficient algorithms that can accurately and rapidly fit Parton Distribution Functions using machine learning models. By leveraging her skills in optimal algorithm design and data processing techniques, Eva is working to streamline the fitting process and improve the speed and accuracy of results. She is particularly excited about experimenting with various optimization strategies that can help in tackling complex problems encountered in her research.

Name: Archi Gupta
Background: Hii, I am a PhD student in the University of Geneva. The goal of my PhD project is to build single photon sources using the platform of rare earth ions. In this project, I am doing simulations based on Tidy3D and using optimisation algorithm like BFGS to determine the optimal parameters for the nano cavity which I want to fabricate to achieve high Purcell enhancement.    Before my PhD, I have also worked with quantum algorithms (BV algorithm) to determine its efficiency over classical algorithm.    I am quite motivated to learn machine learning as it will be really useful in many tasks related to quantum information.
ML_Experience: I don't have any machine learning experience but I am excited to learn about it.
Motivation: I hope to learn more about improving algorithms and machine learning in order to be able to do tasks like error correction and data analysis.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Archi Gupta is focused on developing single photon sources utilizing rare earth ions. His current PhD project at the University of Geneva involves sophisticated simulations with Tidy3D and optimization algorithms such as BFGS. His objective is to identify the optimal parameters for fabricating a nano cavity that achieves significantly high Purcell enhancement, which is crucial for enhancing the efficiency of quantum communication applications.

Before starting his PhD, Archi worked on exploring quantum algorithms, particularly the Bernstein-Vazirani (BV) algorithm. His research aimed to evaluate the efficiency of quantum algorithms in comparison to classical methods. This foundational work provides him with insights into the practical applications of quantum computing and informs his current research endeavors in quantum information and its emerging technologies.

Although Archi Gupta is currently new to machine learning, he is highly motivated to acquire this skill set to enhance his research capabilities within quantum information science. He recognizes the potential of machine learning techniques in improving algorithms for error correction and data analysis, both of which are critical components of his ongoing and future projects in quantum technology.

Name: ALEXANDRA HASLUNDGOURLEY
Background: I'm a Computational Physics Master's student at KU, passionate about the intersection of machine learning and physics. My research interests flow in both directions: I currently work with KU's Dr. Inar Timiryasov and Dr. Jean-Loup Tastet, applying physics-inspired analysis to understand the computational mechanisms of large language models. We focus on analyzing activation matrices produced by these models, employing statistical methods to characterize their behavior as complex dynamical systems.    This summer, and for my thesis work, I plan to explore how diffusion models can predict stable atomic configurations. I'll ground this research using DTU's Computational 2D Materials Database (C2DB), which contains structural, thermodynamic, elastic, electronic, magnetic, and optical properties of approximately 4,000 two-dimensional materials across over 40 different crystal structures. My goal is to incorporate physics priors into these models to produce more reliable and interpretable predictions, following the approach outlined in “A generative artificial intelligence framework based on a molecular diffusion model for the design of metal-organic frameworks for carbon capture”.
ML_Experience: My formal ML education includes courses in unsupervised learning, computer vision, and deep learning. I spent a year as a research fellow at Stanford applying computer vision for environmental monitoring. In my current LLM mechanistic interpretability research, I run inference with and fine-tune open-source models while extracting mid-computation activation matrices for analysis. Additionally, I've used graph neural networks to predict band gap energies of molecules as part of an advanced statistics course.
Motivation: I aim to strengthen my skills in physics-informed machine learning and gain deeper insights into how ML can enhance our modeling and understanding of physical systems. I'm excited to learn from both the distinguished speakers and fellow participants, and to engage in hands-on exercises. I'm particularly interested in methods that integrate physics priors into models, as well as approaches that use physics to interpret and demystify model behavior—an area I consider crucial for making ML more transparent and trustworthy in scientific applications.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Alexandra is deeply engrossed in the exploration of physics-informed machine learning, seeking to integrate physical principles into machine learning models. Her current research revolves around using statistical methods to analyze activation matrices from large language models to understand their behavior as complex dynamical systems. By marrying physics with machine learning, she aims to enhance the interpretability and reliability of these models. This work is crucial in making machine learning applications more transparent, particularly in scientific contexts where understanding the underlying mechanisms is vital.

For her thesis, Alexandra is delving into the use of diffusion models to predict stable atomic configurations, leveraging the Computational 2D Materials Database (C2DB) as a foundational resource. By analyzing structural, thermodynamic, and electronic properties of two-dimensional materials, she intends to incorporate physics priors into her predictive models. This approach not only aims to improve model accuracy but also to provide a clearer understanding of material behaviors at the atomic level, fostering advancements in material science and engineering applications.

Alexandra is focused on improving the interpretability of machine learning models within the realm of physics. Her research includes running inference and fine-tuning open-source models while extracting activation matrices for analysis. She has also employed graph neural networks to predict band gap energies, contributing to the broader goal of making machine learning more transparent. Through her work, she aims to bridge the gap between machine learning and traditional physics modeling, fostering trust in AI applications within scientific research.

Name: Zineb Hayar
Affiliation: University Mohamed V - Faculty of Sciences Rabat
Background: I am a PhD student in Mathematical Physics working on the application of AI to study neutrino signals from astronomical objects in the Hyper-Kamiokande experiment. My research involves analyzing large-scale datasets containing neutrino event features such as energy, time, and spatial distributions. These datasets may be structured and either labeled or unlabeled. Additionally, I focus on the design and development of deployment systems for AI-based data analysis. My goal is to leverage machine learning for event classification, anomaly detection, and enhanced signal extraction.
ML_Experience: I am in the early stages of integrating Machine Learning into my PhD research. I have a strong background in Mathematical Physics and have learned Python through CS50’s Introduction to Programming with Python. I am currently studying AI applications in neutrino physics and learning relevant ML techniques for event classification and signal extraction. While I do not yet have extensive hands-on experience, I am actively developing my skills to apply ML effectively in my research, including data analysis and model deployment.
Motivation: At the school, I hope to deepen my understanding of Machine Learning techniques relevant to physics, particularly for analyzing complex datasets and optimizing AI models. I aim to learn best practices for data preprocessing, feature extraction, and model deployment in a scientific context. With my data, I seek to improve neutrino event classification, enhance signal extraction, and develop a robust deployment system for AI-driven analysis in the Hyper-Kamiokande experiment. Ultimately, I want to bridge the gap between theoretical physics and AI, making meaningful contributions to data-driven discoveries in neutrino astrophysics.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Zineb is investigating the application of artificial intelligence within the realm of neutrino physics, particularly focusing on analyzing neutrino signals derived from astronomical phenomena, as part of the Hyper-Kamiokande experiment. By tackling large-scale datasets that encompass event features such as energy, time, and spatial distributions, she aims to enhance our understanding of neutrino behavior. This research not only involves data analysis but also the practical integration of AI methodologies to improve event classification and anomaly detection in complex datasets.

Zineb is committed to mastering machine learning techniques that are pivotal in the analysis of high-energy particle physics. Through her PhD work, she is enhancing her skills in data preprocessing, feature extraction, and employing strategic AI model deployment. Her academic journey includes learning Python and various ML strategies tailored for real-world applications in scientific research, where she aims to optimize methods for representing and interpreting neutrino event characteristics effectively.

Zineb's research ambitiously bridges the fields of theoretical physics and data science by leveraging machine learning to advance data-driven discoveries in astrophysics. Her focus on neutrinos opens pathways to new insights into cosmic events and particle interactions. She aspires to create robust systems for analyzing and interpreting extensive neutrino datasets, contributing significantly to the field while fostering a deeper understanding of the vast complexities presented by astrophysical phenomena.

Name: Andreas M. Hermansen
Background: I did my MSc improving the Neutrino reconstruction in IceCube using Machine Learning, and am currently doing an interdisciplinary PhD between Physics and Computer Science working on Machine Learning applied to High Energy Physics. In particular I am currently working on how to transfer the success of modern foundation models to the physical sciences. In particular the ATLAS experiment.
ML_Experience: I have was experience working with machine learning models. Both implementing them and using them to properly analyse data. The majority of my MSc degree was spent working on various aspects of data analysis (statistics and ML), which culminated in my Master's thesis which centered around improving the current ML tools used in the IceCube experiment.
Motivation: I hope to meet other early career scientists who have experience with ML, with whom I can share ideas and broaden my view of ML applications in science.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Machine Learning in High Energy Physics
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Andreas is focused on applying machine learning techniques to challenges in high energy physics, particularly in the context of the ATLAS experiment. His work involves not only the implementation of innovative algorithms but also the critical analysis of their performance compared to traditional data analysis methods. By combining his background in physics with advanced computational strategies, Andreas aims to enhance data interpretation and improve experimental outcomes, thus contributing to a deeper understanding of fundamental particles and forces.

With a solid foundation in neutrino physics, Andreas previously enhanced neutrino reconstruction methods during his MSc in the IceCube project, leveraging machine learning to refine data analysis protocols. This experience laid the groundwork for his current investigations into more efficient data processing techniques that can potentially be adapted across various experimental setups in particle physics. His passion for this field drives him to explore new methodologies that could lead to breakthroughs in neutrino science and related areas.

Andreas embodies an interdisciplinary approach by bridging the gap between physics and computer science in his research. He is particularly interested in how modern foundation models of machine learning can be transitioned into applications within physical sciences. By connecting insights from both domains, he seeks to inspire innovative collaborations that could lead to novel solutions for complex problems in physics, enhancing the way data is processed and analyzed in experiments like ATLAS.

Name: Rabia Husain
Background: I am a fourth year PhD student studying particle phenomenology. Specifically I work on problems in collider physics, with a focus on the LHC. I am currently working on a project which aims to improve tagging u vs d jets at the LHC with the inclusion of pT weighted jet charge information. To do so, I am looking at large sets of data generated by Pythia and Delphes. These datasets are around 2M events, formatted as text files which I preprocess into the h5 format before feeding into the networks. We include labels such as momentum, charge, and PID.
ML_Experience: My project on tagging u vs d jets is my first experience using ML. While I have studied the topic previously, I do not have much hands on experience yet, but I hope to incorporate ML into other projects that I am working on. Right now, I am working on another project which aims to reconstruct the rational coefficients of a function given its basis functions by sampling the function and its basis functions at particular points with a given precision. We hope to use ML to help us pick these points, though we have yet to implement this.
Motivation: I hope to learn about more advanced topics in ML at this school, such as representation learning and generative machine learning. Since I am a beginner in the ML field, gaining more knowledge about these topics will help me open up the type of research I am able to do. In addition I would like to learn more about the challenges of ML, including uncertainty quantification. With with this knowledge, I want to improve the techniques I am using to do my current research, as well as expand upon my work into future research directions.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Rabia is focused on collider physics, particularly on the challenges of tagging u vs d jets at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Her current research involves enhancing the tagging process by utilizing pT weighted jet charge information. She analyzes large datasets generated by simulation tools like Pythia and Delphes, processing around 2 million events to optimize the identification of these jets. This work aims to advance the techniques used in particle phenomenology through innovative data handling and analysis.

As a PhD student in her fourth year, Rabia is incorporating machine learning into her research for the first time, aiming to improve tagging processes and other aspects of collider data analysis. While she is still gaining hands-on experience in ML, she is eager to explore advanced topics such as representation learning and generative machine learning. Rabia's goal is to leverage ML methodologies to solve complex problems within her field and enhance her research capabilities.

Rabia recognizes the importance of uncertainty quantification in machine learning applications to particle physics. This understanding is vital for improving the techniques she employs in her current and future projects. By focusing on this aspect, Rabia hopes to foster a more robust application of ML in her field, leading to more reliable results and insights.

Name: Nico Härringer
Background: I work in high-energy physics, focusing on detector development and data analysis within the CMS experiment at CERN. My research includes studying radiation effects on electronics and performing data analysis using the Higgs boson. Primarily, I study the decay of a Higgs into two photons.
ML_Experience: Currently, I don’t have much hands-on ML experience yet, but I’m eager to change that. Motivation: I want to build a solid foundation in Machine Learning and understand how to apply it to HEP problems in a meaningful way. My goal is to gain the confidence to implement ML methods in my own research rather than relying solely on predefined tools. By applying what I learn here, I hope to contribute more effectively to my group and the collaboration.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Nico explores the intricate world of high-energy physics through his work on detector development and data analysis at the CMS experiment at CERN. His research primarily focuses on understanding the effects of radiation on electronics, which is critical for improving the performance and reliability of particle detectors. By investigating the decay of the Higgs boson into two photons, Nico contributes to the broader understanding of fundamental physics and helps pave the way for future discoveries in the field.

Eager to embrace the transformative potential of Machine Learning (ML), Nico aims to integrate these advanced techniques into his research within high-energy physics. Although he currently has limited hands-on experience with ML, he is motivated to develop a comprehensive understanding of these methods, particularly in Physics Object reconstruction. By leveraging ML for applications such as electron and photon analysis, Nico aspires to enhance his research capabilities and enrich his contributions to the scientific community.

Nico is actively engaged in the data analysis of the Higgs boson, particularly studying its decay into two photons, a process that serves as a crucial pathway for probing the properties of the Higgs field and its associated phenomena. This research not only enhances our understanding of particle physics but also aids in refining the capabilities of data analysis tools in high-energy experiments. By addressing challenges in analyzing complex datasets, Nico seeks to uncover new insights that could lead to significant advancements in the field.

Name: Johann Ioannou-Nikolaides

Name: Joaquín Iturriza Ramírez
Background: I'm working on phenomenology in particle physics. At the moment I'm studying the scaling behaviour of different network architectures in the prediction of scattering amplitudes from the momentum of the initial and final particles, varying the number of training data points, loop order, number of particles in the process, etc. Before my current project, as part of my PhD under Anja Butter I worked on the prediction of likelihoods with ML for BSM processes. Specifically focusing on uncertainties using a heteroscedastic loss function.
ML_Experience: Due to my current PhD, I’m working with state of the art architectures for particle physics and methods for uncertainty estimation in ML. So, I have knowledge from the theoretical point of view and in concrete implementations for particle physics.
Motivation: I’m particularly interested in uncertainty estimation and Bayesian NNs, but in general I hope to keep up with the newest advancements and learn new concepts to apply in my PhD research.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Joaquín is delving into the fascinating world of phenomenology in particle physics. His current research focuses on understanding the scaling behavior of various network architectures in predicting scattering amplitudes from the initial and final particles' momentum. By exploring how different factors—such as the number of training data points, loop order, and the number of particles involved—affect these predictions, Joaquín aims to uncover deeper insights into particle interactions and contribute to advancements in the field of particle physics.

In his PhD research, Joaquín is applying machine learning techniques to particle physics. This work involves the use of state-of-the-art architectures and methods for uncertainty estimation, providing him with a robust understanding of both the theoretical aspects and practical implementations of machine learning within this scientific domain. His experience includes predicting likelihoods for beyond standard model (BSM) processes, where he has focused on addressing uncertainties through innovative approaches, such as employing heteroscedastic loss functions.

Joaquín has a keen interest in uncertainty estimation, particularly through the use of Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs). He aims to integrate BNNs into his research to better quantify uncertainties in particle physics predictions. With a strong motivation to stay abreast of the latest advancements in machine learning, Joaquín is committed to exploring novel concepts that can enhance his PhD research, ultimately contributing to more reliable models and predictions in the field of particle physics.

Name: Marc Jacquart

ML_Experience: Multiple academic project in high energy physics (LHCb, CMS & IceCube experiments) for classification and regression of relevant quantities in particle interactions.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Marc is currently focused on inelasticity reconstruction techniques, particularly utilizing the GraphNeT library on simulated data comprising approximately three million neutrino events. With a solid background in high energy physics, Marc is exploring innovative machine learning applications within his academic projects at renowned experiments such as LHCb, CMS, and IceCube. research_interests.research_interest_title: Uncertainty Quantification and Bayesian Neural Networks

Name: Pablo Jimenez
Affiliation: University of Heidelberg, German Cancer Research Center (DKFZ)
Background: My PhD research focuses on Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in medicine, specifically designing MRI protocols for a newly developed local gradient breast coil aimed at early breast cancer detection. The project addresses challenges posed by high gradient inhomogeneities in the coil. One of the possibilities is to apply Machine Learning and Bayesian neural networks to optimize MRI parameters (gradient intensity, diffusion time, b-value) for enhanced diffusion information and better detection of abnormalities, considering the particular gradient inhomogeneities. The dataset consists of 30+ samples, each containing 5 MRI images (128x256 pixels, ~26MB in “twix” format), acquired with varying parameters.
ML_Experience: I have completed a 128-hour postgraduate course on Neural Networks and another 128-hour course on Deep Learning applied to image processing. Additionally, I have worked for 2 years applying Deep Learning techniques for segmentation in medical images. While I am familiar with the core concepts and techniques, I do not have extensive knowledge in Bayesian models or Physics-Informed Neural Networks, which are central to my project.
Motivation: Given that the problem I aim to address with Machine Learning techniques is specific, and my research expertise does not focus on this area, this school could provide me with valuable insights into various projects where groups from unrelated fields are applying these techniques, allowing me to connect them to my own work. I also aim to deepen my understanding of Bayesian and Physics-Informed Neural Networks, learning about their advantages and limitations, which I believe are crucial for the success of this part of my project.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Pablo is focused on the innovative design of Magnetic Resonance Imaging protocols specifically for a newly developed local gradient breast coil. His work is aimed at improving early breast cancer detection by addressing the challenges posed by high gradient inhomogeneities within the device. By developing tailored protocols, he seeks to enhance the imaging capabilities and optimize patient outcomes. This research will directly contribute to advancements in medical imaging technology and potentially lead to earlier diagnoses and better treatment options for breast cancer patients.

Pablo is leveraging Machine Learning techniques, particularly Bayesian neural networks, to refine MRI parameters in his research. His goal is to use data-driven approaches to enhance diffusion information and improve abnormality detection in breast imaging. With a strong foundation in neural networks and deep learning, he aims to extend his knowledge in these areas to optimize parameters like gradient intensity and diffusion time in MRI scans. His research is positioned at the intersection of advanced computing and healthcare, paving the way for more accurate medical diagnostics.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Bayesian Models and Physics-Informed Neural Networks
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Pablo is keen on deepening his understanding of Bayesian models and Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) as these concepts are critical to his PhD project. Name: Julie Kiel Holm

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Julie is focused on the study of stellar streams, which are groups of stars that have a common origin and are moving through space together. By integrating new technologies and methodologies, Julie intends to make significant contributions to the interpretation of this data, facilitating a greater understanding of cosmic structures and the forces that shape them.

Name: Filip Klimovič
Background: My thesis topic lies within the field of condensed matter theory, focusing on terahertz spectroscopy of semiconductor nanostructures, the research of which can possibly lead to miniaturization and energy efficiency enhancement of opto-electronic devices. We develop models to properly describe light-matter interactions on quantum-mechanical level, finding solutions through relatively costly (computational power-wise) finite element method (FEM) electromagnetic calculations. My aim is to optimize the identification of regions of interest in the input parameter space (including all possible geometries of the nanostructured material) for analysis of e.g. plasmonic resonances.
ML_Experience: As a part of my PhD course, I am enrolled in a programme called ‘prg.ai minor’. I have passed subjects on the rigorous foundations of Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence, as well as more applied ones focused on Natural Language Processing. I am still looking for a way to apply ML on my research project.
Motivation: Foremost, I would like to broaden my overview of the new possibilities of ML applications in physics. I understand it is a big thing in experimental data-heavy fields like particle physics and I am interested to see, how condensed matter theory can benefit from the rapid ML development. Concerning my own data, I want to find a smart way of choosing of input parameter set where to look next, based on already calculated results. Finally, I want to start looking into the question, whether some nanostructured metamaterials could be designed to mimic the function of neural networks, such as temporal memory and nonlinear activation.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Filip is focusing on condensed matter theory within his Ph.D. research. Specifically, his work revolves around terahertz spectroscopy of semiconductor nanostructures. This research is crucial for advancing miniaturization and energy efficiency of opto-electronic devices. Through the development of models, he explores light-matter interactions at a quantum-mechanical level, using finite element method (FEM) electromagnetic calculations to find solutions. His goal is to optimize the parameters that govern the behavior of these nanostructures, particularly in identifying regions of interest related to plasmonic resonances.

As a part of his Ph.D. studies, Filip is enrolled in the 'prg.ai minor' program where he has gained knowledge in machine learning and artificial intelligence. Filip is particularly interested in understanding how machine learning can enhance the analysis of complex data in physics, especially in determining optimal input parameter sets based on prior results. His research aims to explore the intersection of machine learning applications in theoretical physics.

Filip's research extends into the innovative realm of nanostructured metamaterials. This aspect of his work aims to bridge the gap between material science and artificial intelligence, offering insights on how advanced materials might be utilized to create more efficient and intelligent opto-electronic devices in the future.

Name: Júlia Križanová

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Júlia is focusing on the intersection of machine learning and optimization within her master's program. Name: Vineet Kumar
Affiliation: Charles University, Faculty of Mathematics and Physics
Background: I am an experimental physicist working in the field of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical (AMO) physics, focusing on the development of quantum technologies such as electron-ion trapping for room-temperature quantum microwave sensing. My work involves analyzing experimental data from fluorescence detection, ion imaging, and noise-signal correlations. These datasets are typically in time-series or image format, with manual or semi-automated labelling. Name: Georg Schwefer
Background: I work in gamma-ray astronomy which is concerned with measuring the highest-energy radiation produced in the universe and understanding its cosmic origin. I work on processing data from ground-based gamma-ray observatories. These “see” gamma-rays through snapshots of the Cherenkov light from the particle-cascades originating from the interactions of the gamma-rays in the atmosphere. Therefore, our datasets are images of particle-cascades, produced at kHz rates each night. The goal is to denoise these images, infer the arrival direction and energy of the original gamma-rays, and filter out background images. These are tasks well-suited to the application of machine learning.
ML_Experience: I have machine-learning experience from courses and research work.    I have taken courses on physics-related machine learning during my master’s and have attended lectures and colloquia on this topic during my PhD too, providing a foundation on methods and terminologies.     On the research side, I have developed a machine-learning-based reconstruction method for Cherenkov images of gamma-ray particle-cascades. This method uses techniques from the field of simulation-based inference and, for the first time, applies them to gamma-ray astronomy. In the context of this, I have also familiarized myself with other machine-learning solutions for this task, such as tree-based methods and CNNs.
Motivation: I think the problems solved by machine learning are quite similar between the subfields of physics, but the language in which they are thought about and thus the solutions can be quite different. I therefore hope to be inspired and learn new approaches and ways of thinking about my tasks from the lecturers and participants with different backgrounds.      In particular, I would like to learn more about the statistical and probabilistic nature and interpretation of machine-learning methods. With this, I would like to achieve more rigorous statistical uncertainties in my inference problems, which has proven difficult so far.
